channel.title: NPR Topics: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Iran protests enter third week under internet blackout
item.description: As Iran's protests enter a third week, the country's president blames foreign powers for the unrest, and warns it will retaliate if the US intervenes militarily.
item.content:encoded: As Iran's protests enter a third week, the country's president blames foreign powers for the unrest, and warns it will retaliate if the US intervenes militarily.
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Historic upset in English soccer's FA Cup as Macclesfield beat holders Crystal Palace
item.description: The result marks the first time in 117 years that a side from outside the major national leagues has eliminated the reigning FA Cup holders.
item.content:encoded:
The result marks the first time in 117 years that a side from outside the major national leagues has eliminated the reigning FA Cup holders.

(Image credit: Michael Regan)
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Latin American left responds to Trump's pledge to take over of Venezuelan oil
item.description: Latin America's left is in disarray after the seizure of Nicolas Maduro and the U.S.'s pledge to take over Venezuela's oil industry. Many on the left are changing their rhetoric about President Trump.
item.content:encoded: Latin America's left is in disarray after the seizure of Nicolas Maduro and the U.S.'s pledge to take over Venezuela's oil industry. Many on the left are changing their rhetoric about President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: After Venezuela, is the world order shifting from diplomacy towards aggression?
item.description: NPR's Sacha Pfeiffer talks with Peter Krause of Boston College about the Trump Administration's willingness to act unilaterally against other countries and what this means for international relations.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Sacha Pfeiffer talks with Peter Krause of Boston College about the Trump Administration's willingness to act unilaterally against other countries and what this means for international relations.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: Venezuela's exiles in Chile caught between hope and uncertainty
item.description: Initial joy among Venezuela's diaspora in Chile has given way to caution, as questions grow over what Maduro's capture means for the country — and for those who fled it.
item.content:encoded:
Initial joy among Venezuela's diaspora in Chile has given way to caution, as questions grow over what Maduro's capture means for the country — and for those who fled it.

(Image credit: JAVIER TORRES)
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett

item.title: Inside a Gaza medical clinic at risk of shutting down after an Israeli ban
item.description: A recent Israeli decision to bar Doctors Without Borders and other aid groups means international staff and aid can no longer enter Gaza or the West Bank. Local staff must rely on dwindling supplies and no international expertise.
item.content:encoded:
A recent Israeli decision to bar Doctors Without Borders and other aid groups means international staff and aid can no longer enter Gaza or the West Bank. Local staff must rely on dwindling supplies and no international expertise.

(Image credit: Anas Baba/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Aya Batrawy

item.title: Iran warns US troops and Israel will be targets if America strikes over protests as death toll rises
item.description: Iran's parliament speaker warned the U.S. military and Israel would be "legitimate targets" if America strikes the Islamic Republic, as threatened by President Donald Trump.
item.content:encoded:
Iran's parliament speaker warned the U.S. military and Israel would be "legitimate targets" if America strikes the Islamic Republic, as threatened by President Donald Trump.

(Image credit: UGC)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Who is Reza Pahlavi, the exiled crown prince encouraging demonstrations across Iran?
item.description: In exile for nearly 50 years, Iran's Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi has issued calls urging Iranians to join protests sweeping the country. But support for him may not be clear cut.
item.content:encoded:
In exile for nearly 50 years, Iran's Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi has issued calls urging Iranians to join protests sweeping the country. But support for him may not be clear cut.

(Image credit: Thomas Padilla)
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: US launches new retaliatory strikes against ISIS in Syria after deadly ambush
item.description: The U.S. has launched another round of strikes against the Islamic State in Syria. This follows last month's ambush that killed two U.S. soldiers and an American civilian interpreter.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. has launched another round of strikes against the Islamic State in Syria. This follows last month's ambush that killed two U.S. soldiers and an American civilian interpreter.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Europe alarmed by Trump's Greenland push
item.description: Europe is increasingly alarmed by Trump's talk of annexing Greenland, an autonomous Danish territory in the EU and NATO, especially after the U.S. incursion in Venezuela last weekend.
item.content:encoded: Europe is increasingly alarmed by Trump's talk of annexing Greenland, an autonomous Danish territory in the EU and NATO, especially after the U.S. incursion in Venezuela last weekend.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley
